
The purpose of this file is to perform extrapolation for weight between measured points, and to use a hierarchical within patient modelling approach to detect outliers. As we have already interpolated height we can use interpolated height, rather than original manually_corrected_height to use as a covariate for the more sophisticated GAM approach with a covariate

Search for the chunK:
Setting limits for extrapolation and scaled residual threshold for assessing outliers
to adjust the parameters for extrapolating outside of the range and for how carefully to look and correct for outliers

*********************
Setting limits for extrapolation and scaled residual threshold for assessing outliers
*********************

```{r, Setting limits for extrapolation and scaled residual threshold for assessing outliers}
print("Whilst we will definitely want to interpolate between points, it becomes more dangerous to extrapolate beyond them. Here we set the limits for both weight and height that we will accept extrapolation. If these are set to zero, then we don't extrapolate at all.")

number_of_years_to_extrapolate_before_for_weight <- 0

number_of_years_to_extrapolate_after_for_weight <- 0

number_of_years_to_extrapolate_before_for_height <- 0

number_of_years_to_extrapolate_after_for_height <- 0

print("We fit GAM models and assess the scaled residual threshold to look for outliers, we set this within the code here. We will need a different figure for GAM models compared to spline and linear interpolations. ")
gam_scaled_residual_threshold_for_weight <- 4

spline_pearson_residual_threshold_for_weight <- 1.2

spline_degrees_of_freedom_less_than_points <- 5

print("The linear interpolation then just fits points between points, it doesn't assess for outliers. Any outlier detection for individual points or overall patients (i.e. those who either have individual outlying points, or who have multiple points but they are all outlying (for instance if their date of birth hadn't been entered correctly and their growth curve was shifted in a direction, would have to have outlier detection within the whole frame)")
```

*******************************************************************************************************************
interpolation of weight within patients using a hierarchical approach with GAM, spline, then straight line interpolations
*******************************************************************************************************************

```{r, using gam in mgcv within patients to create multivariable interpolations for weight using weight and height for patients with 11 observations}
library("mgcv")

require("nlme")

#create empty data frames to join results to
all_gam_weight_height_age_interpolations <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

for (id_to_impute in unique(bp_data$id)){
#for (id_to_impute in 2166){
#for (id_to_impute in 2090){
#for (id_to_impute in 1635){
#id_to_impute <- 996
#id_to_impute <- 1632 # this patient looks like they have a weight outlier - but the model doesn't sink to it unfortunately, showing the limitations of this method
#id_to_impute <- 2166 # this patient looks like they have a weight outlier 

#take out data for our ID    
id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model <- 
  subset(bp_data, id==id_to_impute)  

#print where we are in the loop
print("id is:")
cat(id_to_impute)

print("number of rows for this ID is:")
cat(nrow(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model))

id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model <- 
  subset(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model, 
         !is.na(manually_corrected_weight) &
           !is.na(interpolated_height) &
           !is.na(age_to_use))

print("number of rows with age height and weight to model is:")

cat(nrow(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model))

#pull out the earliest age where we have data for this patient
earliest_age_with_data <- 
  min(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$age_to_use)

oldest_age_with_data <- 
  max(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$age_to_use)

#use our thresholds for extrapolation to define ages above and beyond which we will fit the spline
earliest_age_to_apply_the_model_to_this_patient <- 
  earliest_age_with_data - number_of_years_to_extrapolate_before_for_weight

oldest_age_to_apply_the_model_to_this_patient <- 
  oldest_age_with_data + number_of_years_to_extrapolate_after_for_weight

#skip the modelling if we don't have enough points for multivariable GAM
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$interpolated_height))) < 11 |
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$age_to_use))) < 11 ) next

#collect the id's which were used
all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam_to_join <-
  data.frame(id=id_to_impute)

#join it into a frame outside the loop
all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam <-
  rbind(all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam,
        all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam_to_join)

#take out just the columns for our model and name it the first iteration, as this first iteration will be reiterated if it has outliers
id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration <-
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model[,c(
    "id",
    "id_visit_date",
    "manually_corrected_weight",
    "interpolated_height",
    "age_to_use")]

#fit a gam model wih age and height as a covariate
model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <- 
  mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
            s(age_to_use) + 
            s(interpolated_height) , 
          data=id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration
  )

#we take out our residuals from this model to help with outlier detection
summary(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height)
#plot(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height)

#add residuals to that frame. We use scaled pearson residuals 
id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals <-
  residuals(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height,
          type="scaled.pearson")

#we need a correction here - if the fit is perfect then the residuals will be infinite. we need to change them to zero
id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals <-
  ifelse(
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals=="Inf" |
      id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals=="-Inf",
    0,
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals
  )

#create an absolute version of the residuals to easily compare against our threshold
id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute <-
  ifelse(
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals < 0,
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals * -1,
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals
  )

#pull out the id_visit_date and the residuals from this gam model to add to a frame outside of the loop
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add <-
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration[,c(
    "id_visit_date",
    "model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals")]

#ensure we state the iteration number for these residuals
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add$iteration <- 
  1

#bind them outside of the loop
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame <-
  rbind(all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame,
        all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add)

#########################################################################################
#marking 1st worst residual outlier, removing, and refitting the model
#########################################################################################
#if we have residuals over our threshold, then we mark the biggest residual as an outlier
if (max(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute) > 
    gam_scaled_residual_threshold_for_weight){
  
  #take out the row with the worst residual
  worst_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model <-
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_first_iteration %>% 
    group_by(id) %>%
    slice_max(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute, with_ties = F, n=1)
  
  #pull out that id_visit_date flagged as an outlier, tell us what method and what iteration it came out at
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame_to_add <-
      data.frame(id_visit_date = worst_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model$id_visit_date,
                 manually_corrected_weight_flagged_as_an_outlier_by_gam_age_height = 1,
                 weight_outlier_flag_method = "model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height",
                 weight_gam_age_height_iteration_outlier_was_flagged = 1)
    
    #bind that to the frame outside of the loop
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame <-
      rbind(id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame,
            id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame_to_add)
    
  #create a second iteration frame to remodel
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration <-
      subset(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model, 
             !(id_visit_date %in% id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame$id_visit_date))
  
  #then reinsert our clause to skip to the next iteration in the loop if we've dropped below the threshold to be able to fit a GAM model 
  #realise that this means we may flag some outliers through gam modelling, but will be left without a value for a predicted gam model  
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$interpolated_height))) < 11 |
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$age_to_use))) < 11 ) next

  
  #if we haven't skipped, then we can refit our model without using the data without the outlier point  
    model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <- 
      mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
                s(age_to_use) + 
                s(interpolated_height) , 
                data=id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration
  )
  #add residuals to that second iteration frame. We use scaled pearson residuals 
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals <-
    residuals(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height,
              type="scaled.pearson")
  
  #create an absolute version of the residuals
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute <-
    ifelse(
      id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals < 0,
      id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals * -1,
      id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals
      )

  #pull out the id_visit_date and the residuals from this gam model to add to a frame outside of the loop
  all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add <-
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration[,c(
      "id_visit_date",
      "model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals")]

  #ensure we state the iteration number for these residuals
  all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add$iteration <- 2

  #bind them outside of the frame
  all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame <-
    rbind(all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame,
          all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_frame_to_add)
#########################################################################################
#marking 2nd worst residual outlier, removing, and refitting the model
#########################################################################################    
#if we have residuals over our threshold, then we mark the biggest residual as an outlier
if (max(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute) > 
    gam_scaled_residual_threshold_for_weight){
  worst_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration <-

              n=1)
  
  #pull out that id_visit_date flagged as an outlier, tell us what method and what iteration it came out at
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame_to_add <-
      data.frame(id_visit_date = worst_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration$id_visit_date,

  #bind that to the frame outside of the loop
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame <-
      rbind(id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame,
            id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame_to_add)
  
  #create a third iteration frame to remodel
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_third_iteration <-
      subset(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_second_iteration, 
             !(id_visit_date %in% id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame$id_visit_date))
  
  #then reinsert our clause to skip to the next iteration in the loop if we've dropped below the threshold to be able to fit a GAM model 
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_third_iteration$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_third_iteration$interpolated_height))) < 11 |

  #if we haven't skipped, then we can refit our model without using the data without the outlier point  
    model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <- 
      mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
                s(age_to_use) + 
                s(interpolated_height) ,

  )
    
  #add residuals to that third iteration frame. We use scaled pearson residuals 
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_third_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <-
    residuals(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height,
              type="scaled.pearson")
  
  #create an absolute version of the residuals
  id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_third_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height_residuals_absolute <-

            id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame_to_add)
  
  #create a fifth iteration frame to remodel
    id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fifth_iteration <-
      subset(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fourth_iteration, 
             !(id_visit_date %in% id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_height_frame$id_visit_date))
  
  #then reinsert our clause to skip to the next iteration in the loop if we've dropped below the threshold to be able to fit a GAM model 
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fifth_iteration$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fifth_iteration$interpolated_height))) < 11 |
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fifth_iteration$age_to_use))) < 11 ) next
  
  #if we haven't skipped, then we can refit our model without using the data without the outlier point  
    model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <- 
      mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
                s(age_to_use) + 
                s(interpolated_height) , 
                data=id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_fifth_iteration
  )
  #this is where we stop iterating, and use that as the final model, after four iterations of the worst outlier has been removed  
}}}}

#collect the id's which were used and made it through without outliers being removed to the point where there was no longer enough data to fit a gam
all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam_to_join <-
  data.frame(id=id_to_impute)

#join it into a frame outside the loop
all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam <-
  rbind(all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam,
        all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_height_weight_to_model_for_gam_to_join)


#those iterative if loops above should mean that we have a final gam model that is called model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height fit to the data for that patient having removed any necessary outliers, depending upon the residual threshold we have set

#we don't need to adjust points for outliers at this stage, we have the model fitted to points without outliers. They can get changed during the hierarchical change

#take out our data for that patient again so that we have all of it to fit and impute
new_data_with_height_and_age <-
  data.frame(
    id = bp_data$id,

    age_to_use = bp_data$age_to_use,

  )

#now use that model to interpolate any points for this patient id that are missing

#take out just this patient
new_data_with_height_and_age <-
  subset(new_data_with_height_and_age,

#we take out those without height and age, as we can't fit this model without height and age as they are the predictors
new_data_with_height_and_age <-
  subset(new_data_with_height_and_age,

           !is.na(age_to_use))

#subset just the data that is bounded by our limits of extrapolation
new_data_with_height_and_age <- 
  subset(
    new_data_with_height_and_age,
      age_to_use >= earliest_age_to_apply_the_model_to_this_patient &

  )

#use predict to fit our GAM model and this time call it interpolate
new_data_with_height_and_age$interpolate_weight_using_gam_with_age_height <- 
  predict(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_height, 
          na.action = na.omit,

#join in our interpolations using GAM height and age to the main frame
bp_data_with_gam_weight_height_age_interpolations <-

#flag where we have interpolated a point because it was originally missing. We need to have both a missing original value AND a value for a point that can be used for interpolation - if we didn't have height then we wouldn't be able to use the gam model for weight height and age
```

```{r, using gam in mgcv within patients to create multivariable interpolations for weight using age only for patients with 11 observations}
library("mgcv")

require("nlme")

#create empty data frames to join results to
all_gam_weight_age_interpolations <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_for_gam <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame <- 
  data.frame(NULL)

for (id_to_impute in unique(bp_data$id)){
#for (id_to_impute in 2166){
#for (id_to_impute in 2090){
#for (id_to_impute in 1635){
#id_to_impute <- 996
#id_to_impute <- 1632 # this patient looks like they have a weight outlier - but the model doesn't sink to it unfortunately, showing the limitations of this method
#id_to_impute <- 2166 # this patient looks like they have a weight outlier 
#id_to_impute <- 3739 #this patient was not getting modelled despite having more than 11 points  

#take out data for our ID    
id_data_with_age_weight_to_model <- 
  subset(bp_data, id==id_to_impute)  

#print where we are in the loop
print("id is:")
cat(id_to_impute)

print("number of rows for this ID is:")
cat(nrow(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model))

id_data_with_age_weight_to_model <- 
  subset(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model, 
         !is.na(manually_corrected_weight) &
           !is.na(age_to_use))

print("number of rows with age and weight to model is:")

cat(nrow(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model))

#pull out the earliest age where we have data for this patient
earliest_age_with_data <- 
  min(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model$age_to_use)

oldest_age_with_data <- 
  max(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model$age_to_use)

#use our thresholds for extrapolation to define ages above and beyond which we will fit the spline
earliest_age_to_apply_the_model_to_this_patient <- 
  earliest_age_with_data - number_of_years_to_extrapolate_before_for_weight

oldest_age_to_apply_the_model_to_this_patient <- 
  oldest_age_with_data + number_of_years_to_extrapolate_after_for_weight

#skip the modelling if we don't have enough points for multivariable GAM
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model$age_to_use))) < 11 ) next

#take out just the columns for our model and name it the first iteration, as this first iteration will be reiterated if it has outliers
id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration <-
  id_data_with_age_weight_to_model[,c(
    "id",
    "id_visit_date",
    "manually_corrected_weight",
    "age_to_use")]

#fit a gam model wih age as a predictor
model_weight_using_gam_with_age <- 
  mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
            s(age_to_use)  , 
          data=id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration
  )

#we take out our residuals from this model to help with outlier detection
summary(model_weight_using_gam_with_age)
#plot(model_weight_using_gam_with_age)

#add residuals to that frame. We use scaled pearson residuals 
id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals <-
  residuals(model_weight_using_gam_with_age,
          type="scaled.pearson")
#we need a correction here - if the fit is perfect then the residuals will be infinite. we need to change them to zero
id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals <-
  ifelse(
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals=="Inf" |
      id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals=="-Inf",
    0,
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals
  )

#create an absolute version of the residuals to easily compare against our threshold
id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_absolute <-
  ifelse(
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals < 0,
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals * -1,
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals
  )

#pull out the id_visit_date and the residuals from this gam model to add to a frame outside of the loop
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame_to_add <-
  id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration[,c(
    "id_visit_date",
    "model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals")]

#ensure we state the iteration number for these residuals
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame_to_add$iteration <- 
  1

#bind them outside of the loop
all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame <-
  rbind(all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame,

#########################################################################################

if (max(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_absolute) > 
    gam_scaled_residual_threshold_for_weight){
  
  #take out the row with the worst residual
  worst_id_data_with_age_weight_to_model <-
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_first_iteration %>%

    slice_max(model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_absolute, with_ties = F, n=1)
  
  #pull out that id_visit_date flagged as an outlier, tell us what method and what iteration it came out at
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame_to_add <-
      data.frame(id_visit_date = worst_id_data_with_age_weight_to_model$id_visit_date,
                 manually_corrected_weight_flagged_as_an_outlier_by_gam_age = 1,
                 weight_outlier_flag_method = "model_weight_using_gam_with_age",
                 weight_gam_age_iteration_outlier_was_flagged = 1)
    
    #bind that to the frame outside of the loop
    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame <-
      rbind(id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame,
            id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame_to_add)
    
  #create a second iteration frame to remodel
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration <-
      subset(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model, 
             !(id_visit_date %in% id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame$id_visit_date))
  
  #then reinsert our clause to skip to the next iteration in the loop if we've dropped below the threshold to be able to fit a GAM model 
  #realise that this means we may flag some outliers through gam modelling, but will be left without a value for a predicted gam model  
if (sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration$manually_corrected_weight))) < 11 | 
    sum(!is.na(unique(id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration$age_to_use))) < 11 ) next

  
  #if we haven't skipped, then we can refit our model without using the data without the outlier point  
    model_weight_using_gam_with_age <- 
      mgcv::gam(manually_corrected_weight ~ 
                s(age_to_use)  , 
                data=id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration
  )
  #add residuals to that second iteration frame. We use scaled pearson residuals 
  id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals <-

      id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration$model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals
      )

  #pull out the id_visit_date and the residuals from this gam model to add to a frame outside of the loop
  all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame_to_add <-
    id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_second_iteration[,c(
      "id_visit_date",
      "model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals")]

  #ensure we state the iteration number for these residuals
  all_model_weight_using_gam_with_age_residuals_frame_to_add$iteration <- 2

#########################################################################################
#marking 2nd worst residual outlier, removing, and refitting the model

#if we have residuals over our threshold, then we mark the biggest residual as an outlier

    id_visit_dates_with_weight_flagged_as_outliers_from_gam_age_frame_to_add <-
```

```{r, using smooth.spline basic function within patients to create interpolations for weight using weight for patients with less than 11 observations but more than 3 observations}
         spline_interpolated_data$manually_corrected_weight)

#restrict to just this patient

  subset(spline_interpolated_data, 
         id==id_to_impute)

#take out just the necessary columns

)]

#join in our information about outliers
```

```{r, using approxfun to interpolate between points that have less than 4 observations for weight}
         !(id %in% all_ids_with_enough_id_data_with_age_weight_to_model_for_gam$id)   )

cat(nrow(unique(all_ids_without_enough_data_for_spline_or_gam_weight_interpolation_frame)))

for (id_to_impute in unique(all_ids_without_enough_data_for_spline_or_gam_weight_interpolation_frame$id)){

#id_to_impute <- 757 # this patient has four visits but only 2 weight measurements, so we interpolate betweeen
#id_to_impute <- 1256 # this patient has four visits but only 2 weight measurements, so we interpolate betweeen

id_data <- 
  subset(bp_data, id==id_to_impute)  

print("id is:")
print(id_to_impute)
print("number of rows is:")
print(nrow(id_data))

#skip if we don't have 2 data points to model and give a message
if (sum(!is.na(id_data$manually_corrected_weight)) < 2) {
  print("Unable to interpolate this patient has less than 2 points available that are known")
  #collect the id before we skip out of the loop for this patient
  ids_with_insufficient_data_for_linear_interpolation_of_weight_to_add <-
    data.frame(id=unique(id_data$id))
  #bind that outside of the loop
  ids_with_insufficient_data_for_linear_interpolation_of_weight <-
    rbind(
      ids_with_insufficient_data_for_linear_interpolation_of_weight,
      ids_with_insufficient_data_for_linear_interpolation_of_weight_to_add
    )
  
}
if (sum(!is.na(id_data$manually_corrected_weight)) < 2) next

id_data <-
  id_data[,c(
    "id",
    "manually_corrected_weight",
    "age_to_use",
    "id_visit_date")]

#fit a linear interpolation model
id_data$linear_interpolation <- 
  stats::approx(
    x=id_data$age_to_use,
    y=id_data$manually_corrected_weight,
    xout=id_data$age_to_use,
    method="linear",
    rule=1:1)$y # rule=1 means we don't extrapolate either side. if you use rule=2, then the adjacent data point is used for extrapolation. can use rule = 2:1 to do a different rule at beginning and end of data

#check to see if we have an interpolated point and flag it - this must include that we don't extrapolate

id_data$linear_interpolated_weight_flag <-
  ifelse(is.na(id_data$manually_corrected_weight) &
           !is.na(id_data$linear_interpolation),
         1,
         0)

id_data$linear_interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(is.na(id_data$manually_corrected_weight),
         id_data$linear_interpolation,
         id_data$manually_corrected_weight)

  
linear_interpolated_data_to_bind <- 
  id_data[,c(
    "id_visit_date",

    "manually_corrected_weight",

  geom_point(data=subset(linear_interpolated_data_to_bind,

    aes(), alpha=0.5, colour="blue") +
  
  geom_point(data=subset(linear_interpolated_data_to_bind, 
                         linear_interpolated_weight_flag==1),
    aes(), alpha=0.5, colour="orange") +
  
  geom_line(aes(x=age_to_use, 
             y=linear_interpolated_weight)) + 
  
  labs(title="Blue is original data, 
       orange is interpolated missing data point, 
       no outliers are flagged by linear interpolation",
       subtitle=paste0("Number of interpolated points = ",
                       sum(linear_interpolated_data_to_bind$linear_interpolated_weight_flag==1))) +
  themepowerpointtitle

linear_interpolated_plot

dir.create("linear_weight_interpolation_plots")
dir.create("linear_weight_interpolation_plots/individual_imputations")

ggsave(filename=paste0("id_", id_to_impute, ".tif"),

       device="tiff",

       height=5, 
       compression = "lzw",

if(sum(
  linear_interpolated_data_to_bind$linear_interpolated_weight_flag==1) > 0 ){

}
}
```

```{r, use the hierarchy to insert weight imputations and give us a column that tells us how our weight was interpolated}
#if we have a value for linear interpolation then we use it as bottom rung of the hierarchy
bp_data$interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$linear_interpolated_weight),
         bp_data$linear_interpolated_weight,
         NA)
#categorise the method we have used if we have used that
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$linear_interpolated_weight),
         "linear_interpolation",
         NA)

#we use a spline value in preference to this if we have it (note, we shouldnt have both if we've only run the algorithm through necessary patients) It may be in future, because you do have the option of running the spline and the linear interpolation through also, I've just not done that to prevent outliers being flagged by some methods and not by others and therefore creating ambiguity
bp_data$interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$spline_interpolated_weight),
         bp_data$spline_interpolated_weight,
         bp_data$interpolated_weight)
#categorise the method we have used if we have used that
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$spline_interpolated_weight),
         "spline_interpolation",
         bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)

#we use a gam model with just weight from age if we have that
bp_data$interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age),
         bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age,
         bp_data$interpolated_weight)
#categorise the method we have used if we have used that
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age),
         "gam_interpolation_just_age",
         bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)

#we use a gam model with weight from age and height if we have that
bp_data$interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age_height),
         bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age_height,
         bp_data$interpolated_weight)
#categorise the method we have used if we have used that
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$gam_interpolated_weight_using_age_height),
         "gam_interpolation_from_age_and_height",
         bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)

#if we dont have an interpolated weight, but we do have a manually_corrected_weight, then we just insert the manually_corrected_weight. This will not have been flagged as an outlier otherwise there would be an interpolated value for it
bp_data$interpolated_weight <-
  ifelse(is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight),
         bp_data$manually_corrected_weight,
         bp_data$interpolated_weight)

#if we have a value for the original and our interpolation is the same as the original, then we can say that the value we are using is original
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections) & 
           bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections==bp_data$interpolated_weight,
         "original_measurement",
         bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)

#then we can say that any remaining NA values we are unable to interpolate
bp_data$interpolated_weight_method <-
  ifelse(is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight_method),
         "unable_to_interpolate",
         bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)

print("Check that the number we are unable to interpolate is the same as the number we don't have an interpolated weight value for. This number should be zero:")
sum(is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight)) - sum(bp_data$interpolated_weight_method=="unable_to_interpolate")
print("Summary statistics for weight before outlier corrections:")
descr(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections)
print("Summary statistics for weight after outlier corrections:")
descr(bp_data$interpolated_weight)
print("Number of readings before outlier corrections")
sum(!is.na(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections))
print("Number of registered methods of interpolation (this number should be the same)")
sum(!is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight_method))
print("This number should NOT be zero because we should have extra points interpolated, otherwise please review interpolation hierarchy")
sum(!is.na(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections)) - sum(!is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight_method))
print("The interpolation method frequencies are as follows:")
freq(bp_data$interpolated_weight_method)


weight_interpolation_visual_check <-
  bp_data[,c(
    "id",
    "manually_corrected_weight",
    "interpolated_weight",
    "interpolated_weight_method"
  )]

print("You can look at weight_interpolation_visual_check to see what's happening. We could increase data further by extrapolating for patients with some readings. Some patients don't have any readings - they could be imputed completely, for instance with age, sex, height and centre. Wouldn't want to have them change weight, but could do multiple imputation of weight that doesn't change in each dataset. Could also detect outlying patients and readings from those without many readings in the data set as a whole")
```

```{r, we want an overall flag for whether a value has been interpolated because it is missing, or interpolated because it is an outlier}
bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_missing <-
  ifelse(is.na(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections) &
           !is.na(bp_data$interpolated_weight),
         1,
         0)
#freq(bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_missing)

bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_outlier <-
  ifelse(!is.na(bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections) &
           bp_data$manually_corrected_weight_before_outlier_corrections!=bp_data$interpolated_weight,
         1,
         0)
#freq(bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_outlier)

print("we have interpolated the following number of weights because they were missing:")
sum(bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_missing)
print("we have interpolated the following number of weights because they were flagged as outliers and replaced with interpolation:")
sum(bp_data$interpolated_weight_flag_because_outlier)
print("Remember, you can adjust the residual thresholds to flag things as outliers at the top of this file if necessary")
```
